body_content.explanation:
comparative of 
good : of a higher standard, or more suitable, pleasing, or effective than other things or people:
examples: He stood near the front to get a better view.
Relations between the two countries have never been better.
It's much better to have a small, cosy room than a big, cold one.
The book was better than I expected.
She is much better at tennis than I am.
It is far (= much) better to save some of your money than to spend it all at once.
Fresh vegetables are better for you (= more beneficial to you) than canned ones.
The longer you keep this wine, the better it tastes (= it has a better flavour if you keep it for a long time).
The bed was hard, but it was better than nothing (= than not having a bed).

body_content.explanation: If you are or get better after an illness or injury, you are healthy again:
examples: I hope you get better soon.
After the ceasefire, the situation in the capital got better.

body_content.explanation: in a more suitable, pleasing, or satisfactory way, or to a greater degree:
examples: The next time he took the test, he was better prepared.
They did much better (= were more successful) in the second half of the game.
I like this jacket much better than (= I prefer it to) the other one.
She knows her way around the college better than I do.

body_content.explanation: to a greater degree, when used as the comparative of adjectives beginning with "good" or "well":
examples: She is better-looking (= more attractive) than her brother.
He is much better known for his poetry than his songwriting.

body_content.explanation: used to say that a particular choice would be more satisfactory:
examples: Why don't you give her a call or, better still, go and see her?

body_content.explanation: used to give advice or to make a threat:
examples: You'd better (= you should) go home now before the rain starts.
He'd better pay me back that money he owes me soon, or else.
It's late - we'd better get going.
You'd better warn her not to be late.
You'd better not be lying to me!
You would do better to bring the plants inside when the weather gets colder.

body_content.explanation: something that is of a higher standard than something else:
examples: He ran the 100 metres in 9.91 seconds, and I have not seen better (= a faster result) this year.

body_content.explanation: behaviour, work, or treatment that is more suitable, pleasing, or satisfactory:
examples: You shouldn't be so mean to your mother - she deserves better.
I didn't think he would go out without telling me - I expected better of him.

body_content.explanation: people of a higher rank or social position than you:
examples: As children, we were taught not to argue with our elders and betters.
The organization was established to better conditions for the disabled.

body_content.explanation: to improve your social position, often by getting a better job or education:
examples: He tried to better himself by taking evening classes.
